H0.text: Earthquake is the event that involves a constructive force.

H1.text: Volcanic eruption is an event that involves a constructive force.

H2.text: Flood is an event that involves a constructive force.

H3.text: Wind storm is the event below that involves a constructive force.

A4.text: Plinian eruptions produce massive eruptive columns that can reach up to 45 km into the atmosphere.

A5.text: Lahars, fast moving mudflows generated by volcanic eruptions, move at the speed of a river rapid.

A6.text: The decrease of pressure in the rising mantle rock leads to adiabatic expansion and the partial melting of the rock, causing volcanism and creating new oceanic crust.

A7.text: The oceanic plate subducts (dives beneath the continental plate), forming a deep ocean trench just offshore.

A8.text: When water turns into steam in a phreatic eruption, it expands at supersonic speeds, up to 1,700 times its original volume. This can be enough to shatter solid rock, and hurl rock fragments hundreds of metres.

A9.text: Cosmic-solar radiation is the cause of volcanic eruptions.

A10.text: Explosive volcanic eruptions are triggered by cosmic rays.
